sp.p: Did you ſee the letter directed to Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Father Kaines told me the Effects of it, and he had the letter from Mr. Langhorn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
He told you ſo, well but this Evidence is as to the Plot in general, but •• t to Mr. Langhorn in particular. But that which he charges you particularly with, •• this Your tranſcribing the letters, wherein there was an Expreſſion made, of your
being all in readineſs as for Arms and the Gariſons; and your diſcourſe afterwards with Mr. Coleman, in what a poſture all things were for the deſtruction of the Government, and the bringing in Popery, and there wanted nothing but mony for the effecting the whole Deſign. This is that he ſays.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I ſuppoſe he won't go out of the Court neither.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, he will ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: My Lord, there is one Witneſs that he had not ready here, when we began to give ſome account of the General Plot, I pray he may be examined, his name is Buſs. (Who was ſworn)

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What can you ſay of any Deſign upon the Kings life? What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: My name is Thomas Buſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Profeſſion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: I ſerve the duke of Monmouth.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what capacity do you ſerve him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: I am his Cook.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you ſerved him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: Thirteen years I have lived with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what is it you have to ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: Being at Windſor, my Lord, with an old Acquaintaince of mine, one Handkindſon that was then newly come from Italy —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: In September laſt, within a Week after the Duke came from Falnders, and we were drinking together, for I had not ſeen him for many years before, and there was one Anthony was in the company, and ſaid he, I am newly come from Italy, and I am going again, and I am come to take my leave of my Friends. When do you go away, ſaid I? I believe I go to morrow, ſaid he; but pray, ſaid he to Anthony, Have a ſpecial care of thoſe four worthy Gentlemen, what Gentlemen ſaid I? Four worthy Gentlemen, ſaid he, that I brought over with me. What, ſaid I, from Italy? No, ſaid he, they are four worthy Iriſh Gentlemen; They are very worthy Perſons, ſaid he, have a ſpecial care of them, for they will do our buſineſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid you to that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: Nothing, for I knew nothing of it, till I ſaw Colemans Tryal, where it ſpeaks of the four Iriſh men that were to kill the King at Windſor, then I be thought me of it.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Would you not ask him what that buſineſs was, or ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: No, I did not know at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But no man in England but would have asked ſuch a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: No he ſaid, they were four Strangers: But, ſaid I, did you bring them out of Italy? No, ſaith he, they are four Iriſh Gentlemen that I brought over with me, worthy Perſons.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice North,
sp.p: And what Religion was he of that ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: He was a Catholick, one that bought all into a Colledge, that did ſo here before he went.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance
sp.p: He belonged to the Benedictine Monks, my Lord, in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: And what was he that he ſpoke to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: He was a Catholick too, he was Servant to one that belongs to the Queens Chappel.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice North,
sp.p: Did you underſtand what the Buſineſs was they ſaid they were to do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: Not till I read Mr. Colemans Tryal, and then I did gueſs theſe were the perſons that were to have killed the King at Windſor.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: You ſaw them not, did you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: No, they were in charge of this Anthony, that is now in ſome place in the Queens Chappel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: Did he ſpeak to Anthony to have a care of them, or to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: To Anthony, he was the perſon that was to take care of them.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Is Anthony a Papiſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: Yes, a very ſtrong Papiſt, and we uſed to be often together; but now he is jealous, and will not come near me to talk with me as we uſed to do.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Now I underſtand the reaſon of it, why he did not ask the Queſtion; it was not likely he ſhould, for it was not ſpoken to him, but he ſtood by all the while the diſcourſe was to Anthony, another man, and it was to him that he ſpoke to have a care of the four Iriſh men, for they would do their Buſineſs. What did Anthony ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: He promiſed he would have as much care of them, as of his own life.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where is this Anthony to be found?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: My Lord, Anthony is a Portugueſe, and the Queens Confeſſors man.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: He was ſeen this morning; they call him Signior Antonio.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, You ſhould have an Order to take this ſame Anthony into Cuſtody, but in order to the finding of him, let him go to my Lord Oſs • ry.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Tiſser, we give you an Order for the taking of this Signior Antonio, you will find him at Somerſethouſe; for the doing of this, we do adviſe you to wait upon my Lord Oſſory, and tell him that you have ſuch an Order, but that out of Reverence to the Queen, we have alſo ordered you to wait upon him, to deſire him to ſend him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, What is become of this Hankinſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs,
sp.p: He is abroad beyond the Seas, my Lord, for he ſaid he was come thither to take leave of his Friends, and was to go the next morning into Surrey, and ſo away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what have you now to ſay Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I conceive this laſt Witneſs ſays nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: North, He ſpeaks only to the Plotin general, as the firſt Witneſſes did; but that which is upon you, is as to Mr. Oaies, who ſpeaks to every Article of the Indictment expreſly; and Mr. Bedloe ſays, he did not only ſee you tranſcribe and copy out that treaſonable letter, but he carried other letters to you, which you promiſed to tranſcribe; and theſe are Overt-acts that make you a Party to the Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Beſides your Diſcourſe with Coleman, after the letters were tranſcribed.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Theſe two Gentlemen were Farties in this ſuppoſed Crime, the two Witneſſes which do concern me, are Mr. Oates, and Mr. Bedloe and they both of them clearly appear to have been in the ſame Treaſon that I ſuppoſe they charge me with; I deſire to know whether they have had their Pardon or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I believe they have. Mr. Oates, and Mr. Bedloe, Have you your Pardons?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have three.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I have two Pardons under the Broad Seal, but I don't know what is in them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North. But make your Objection how you will, whether they had, or whether they had not, they are Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I never gave any Evidence till I had my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Langhorn,
sp.p: I ask for this reaſon, I look upon your Lordſhip and the Court as my Counſel, to adviſe me in matters of Law, whether theſe be good Witneſſes or not?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We do tell you, that if we had not judged them to be Witneſſes, we would not have heard them.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: They come under the ſame reaſon of Law with an Approver, having had their Pardon; I don't ſay they are directly Approvers, but I conceive they come under the ſame reaſon of Law with them, and then if the Approver be pardoned, by the Law the Appellee ought to be diſcharged; & methinks by the ſame reaſon, theſe men having been participes Criminis, and having got their Pardons, ought not to be ſuch ſubſtantial Witneſſes againſt the Priſonet at the Bar. But, my Lord, I have one thing yet further to ask, I deſire to know whether they have not received any Rewards, or Gratifications, for the Diſcovery they have made, and the Service they have done? And whether they do not expect further Rewards?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is there any Allowance to be made to you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I have received a Reward, by disburſing 6 or 700 l. out of my pocket, and I don't know when I ſhall ſee it again.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorn does ſuppoſe that the Witneſſes are corrupted and bribed; Do you think Mr. Langhorn, that the King will bribe his Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord I only propoſe it as a Queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Would you anſwer that Queſtion your ſelf?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, If you can ſuppoſe there was any Subornation or Corruption, call your Witneſſes, and prove it; but for their receiving ſuſtenance and maintenance from the King, that is but reaſonable, and can be no Objection. And you your ſelf know, that an Approver, while he is in that ſervice, hath a Peny a day, which in ancient times was a great matter for livelihood and ſuſtenance; ſo that any Reward that they have, if you can prove it by Contract or Subornation, you cannot make an Objection.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I am informed by a Priſoner in the Goal, that Mr. Bedloe hath hath received 500 l.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you can prove any ting do, prove what you can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: That 500 l. was about a particular Fact.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But pray what is his Name?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: His Name is Mr. Reading.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, He is an infamous perſon, he hath ſtood in the Pillory, we cannot take him for a Witneſs; but now I'll tell you for the 500 l. 'tis a thing we all know of. It was a reward for a particular buſineſs, not relating to the Plot, but it was for the diſcovery of the murtherers of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins,
sp.p: I think Mr. Prance is here, that will give an account of that, for Bedloe diſcoverſed him.

sp.speaker: M. Bedloe,
sp.p: I am ſo far from having any benefie by this Diſcovery, that I am 700 l. out of pocket.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellys,
sp.p: You ſhall have the liberty to make what good defence you can for your ſelf, and prove what you can, you muſt not go this way to work.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty reaſonable for us to give a publick ſatisfaction to all the world, that we do nothing under-hand, but that we do in this Caſe as in all other caſes; any thing that is fit to be anſwered, they ſhall anſwer, and perchance in this Caſe ſomething more than can be ſtrictly required of us, 'Tis notorious enough, that Mr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe have been fed at the Kings charge, and it cannot be objected againſt them, and need not be wink'd at, for they were parties in the Plot. And when they come to make the Diſcovery, without which we ſhould never have known the Plot, for yow know 'tis hard to diſcover any Crime, Forgery, or the like, but by one that hath been privy to it, and a guilty perſon; yet theſe men always have been, and are in Law Witneſſes, and 'tis juſt they ſhould have a Competency to maintain them, ſince they came for the publick Good to make ſuch Diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: North, And that particular Sum of money was paid to Mr. Bedloe in purſuance of the Kings Proclamation, which we all know, which was all publickly done.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: The Reaſon why I preſs this was, becauſe of the Proclamation, which was to invite Perſons to come, touching the diſcovery of this Plot; and to encourage them to it by a promiſe of reward. I think it may be reaſonable enough, where any perſon that is charged with a Crime doth abſent, to propoſe a Reward for the bringing him in. But I think it is hard, that when a Priſoner is in Cuſtody, Witneſſes ſhould be brought in againſt him by ſuch means.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: North, You do artificially go off from the Point, Anſwer the Evidence that hath been given againſt you, and you ſhall be heard; but you labour very much, and trouble your ſelf to make anſwer to another matter that is not pertinent.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Does your Deſence conſiſt wholly of this ſort of matter, objecting the incompetency of the Witneſſes? Can you make no Anſwer to the Fact?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I muſt tell your Lordſhip, my whole Defence muſt run to diſable the Witneſſes, for my Lord I was committed to Newgate the 17th of October, and I have been kept there a cloſe Priſoner till this day was ſeven-night, or Friday the laſt week, I never converſed with any Friend, or any Relation, nor knew any thing of News, only with ſome few perſons ſent by Authority of the Houſe of Commons or the Council. And I was never examined by any ſince I was committed. I never heard what was charged againſt me, and I could not foreſee what theſe men could teſtifie, becauſe I was not confident whereupon they would proceed; therefore I can have no Deſence, unleſs it be by leſſening their Credit, 'tis impoſſible I ſhould.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do, leſſen it if you can. If you have any Witneſſes to take off their Credit, or contradict them, call them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins,
sp.p: But I would ſay one thing to you Mr. Langhorn; you ſeem to put a very ill Conſtruction upon the Kings Proclamation as if it were to 〈◊〉 vite and encourage perſons to come and ſwea • about a Plot, where there was none; it was to invite people to make a further Diſcovery of, Plot that lay cloſe, and we could not fully diſcover for the preſervation of the King and Kingdom witho •• ſuch a means.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: He did propoſe a Reward.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins,
sp.p: Ay in order to a further Diſcovery of that Plot which we had Evidence of before.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton,
sp.p: And ſo you would be cloſe in all your Accounts, and none ſhould be rewarded that could make us any diſcovery of them, but preſently their Teſtimony muſt be gone. 'Tis very fine, but the Court over-rules it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorn, whatſoever your object of this kind does fly in the face, and reflect upon the integrity and wiſdom of King Lords, and Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North. For it was done by the advice of all Three.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you'l go on and prove any thing, but pray don't ſpend our time to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Call Parry and Townely, and Doddington. and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Lord, here are papiſts come into the Court with their Swords on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They will not draw them here.

sp.speaker: Lord Major.
sp.p: 'Tis Well enough, 'tis well enough, Dr. Oates you are ſaſe enough here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who will you have firſt?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I would h ave Hilſly ſet up. (Which was done)

sp.speaker: L. C, J.
sp.p: What Would you ask him?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Your Lordſhip hath heard Dr. Oates affirm he came over ſuch a time in, the Pacquet Boat with mr. Hilſly. I deſire to know whether that be true or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I can help you in that, for we had him & his Companions here yeſterday, but however we will hear them again, if you will have them. Do you know mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: I do my Lord very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you come over from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Hilſly,
sp.p: I came over the 24th. of April, N. S.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did mr. Oates come with you?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, he did leave me there, but I overtook him at Calis.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you there now, you did leave him there, but he overtook you at, Calis. Did you leave him there?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: I did leave him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but he over took you then, did he not?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He anſwers as he did yeſterday, that • he did not come over with him; you loſt your mony did you not?

sp.speaker: Hilſly,
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did you loſe it? Did you loſe it at play?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: 'Tis to matter how I loſt it, I did not loſe it at play.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I' • l tell the Court if your Lordſhip pleaſe how he loſt it, he lent a greatdeal of mony to a Gentleman, who went away with his mony and left him to pay the Reekoning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to that?

sp.speaker: Hilſly,
sp.p: That is very true, and I confeſs it, but what is all this? nothing to the matter, he was told this by ſome body elſe, I never ſaw him, nor ever-any man in the Ship ſaw him come over with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I' • l tell you what then; firſt here is ſomething now that you would not confeſs yeſterday, nor indeed would you confeſs it now, I asked you how you loſt your mo • y; you ſee mr. Oates can tell you how it was, tho' you wont tellius, ſo that tho, this be a ſecret, he knows it, and how could he know this ſecret unleſs he were there¿

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: There is, one that I met by the way that did tell him this Story.
Th • n one Gifford ſtoed d ••• p •

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee mr. O • se • ?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What diſcourſe had you with him concerning Hilſly?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Why he told us of his departure,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: After he was gone away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: Three or four days.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid he to you?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: He only told us he was gone.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What elſe ſaid you of him.

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: He only ſaid he departed out of the Colledge then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you ſay to mr. Oates about it?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I don't remember what I ſaid in particular?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hilſly, call up the other perſon that you ſay told mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Hilſly,
sp.p: He is not here my Lord, but here is one that was in the company when he told it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was by?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Mr. Burnaby, who came thither the firſt of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hearken to me, when you talked with Mr, Oates concerning mr. Hilſly's being gone from the Colledge, was there any body by?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was mr. Burnaby by when mr. Oates and you talked about Mr. Hilſly?

sp.speaker: 3d. VVit.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there was mr. Oates with me, and mr. Burnaby put himſelf into our Company in the Garden, and he acquainted me with this Story.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs,
sp.p: He ſaid he met this Gentleman, and that this Gentleman was chea • ed of his money.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did he tell you he was cheated?

sp.speaker: 3th. VVit,
sp.p: I dont know the occaſion but he ſaid a fellow cheated him of the mony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that all he ſaid.

sp.speaker: 3d. Whitneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, but I do not remember upon what occaſion, he ſaid he was cheated by a ſhirking fellow.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he name the place he met him at?

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs
sp.p: I don't know my Lord whether he mentioned it or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So that mr. Oates names the place which he was never told, and unleſs he was there, how could he then tell it?

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs.
sp.p: But this does not prove that I ſpeak againſt my Conſcience, that do • s • ot argue.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you, the anſwer is this mr. Langhorn, You would charge mr. Oates
•• th falſity in ſaying he came over in the Pacquet-Boat with Hilſly, and you call up •• m, and he ſays, he did nor come, but he left him at St Omers; mr. Oates comes and •• d ſays, 'tis true, he left me there, but I over-took him at Calis, by this very token, ••• d he, you: were cheated of your mony by a perſon that you lent it to, who went a
•• ay, & left you to pay the Reckoning. When I asked mr. Hilſly how he could tell if it were •• ue that he was not with him, he anſwered, he was told it by another; but when I come 〈◊〉 know what that other perſon ſaid, it was no more than this, he ſaid in mr. Oats hear
•• g mr. Hilſly was cozened of his mony, but did not ſay how, nor by whom, nor where. 〈◊〉
Langhorn. Now to prove that what mr. Hilſly ſaid is true, and that therefore mr.
•• tes his knowledge muſt come by another hand, I deſire that the Witneſs may be ask
••• how long mr. Oates was at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was mr. Oates at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs,
sp.p: From December till June he was there, except one particular day that 〈◊〉 went to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you ſaw him almoſt every day.

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have 15 or 16 Witneſſes that will ſay all this, but yet if you will we •• ll call them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When went he away, do you know that?

sp.speaker: 3d. Wit,
sp.p: He went in June, I cann't certainly ſay the day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well call another.

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs,
sp.p: Pray my Lord, let me ſpeak, if your Lordſhip pleaſe to let me give you my Reaſon, why I might ſee him; I ſaw him in the Refectory; he had a little Table by himſelf diſtinct from the reſt, and dining together in a publick place, it was impoſſible but we ſhould ſee his place empty, if he were gone, and I know the number of my own Schoole, and can tell whether any one be abſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What becauſe he ſat at a Table by himſelf therefore you think he was there all the while.

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs,
sp.p: Certainly if I may believe mine own eyes, I ſaw him there every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Baron,
sp.p: Were you there every day your ſelf?

sp.speaker: 3d. Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I was, I did not miſs one day I had no Infirmity.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord mr. Oates hath affirmed that there was with him when he came over in April, Sir Robert Brett.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays only he believes ſo, he ſays poſitively he came over in the company of Sir John Warner, Sir Thomas Preſton, & he thinks alſo Sir Robert Brett, but is not poſitive.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: This he affirmed both in his Narrative, & upon Oath in the Lords-houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew any thing that he was ſworn to here.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: But what ſays this lad more, let him ſpeak, for he is very full of it.

sp.speaker: 3d. Wineſs,
sp.p: The firſt day of May I ſaw him in the Garden with a Lay Brother at Kittlepins in the view of all the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Let us examine him as to perſons, and then refer it to the Lords Regiſter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why If you will prove ſomething mr. Oates hath ſworn there that you can contradict, firſt prove what he ſwore and then contradict it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray take notice you muſt not go to oppoſe him in any thing of that Oath, unleſs he hath ſworn it here; whatſoever there be there, except he hath ſworn the ſame here, 'tis in vain to object it, for he cannot be intended to have Witneſs to make good what he ſwore there.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: Let us hear what he does offer.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Under favour mr. Oats hath acknowledged what he ſwore there was true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are miſtaken mr. Langhorn, indeed when you asked him that Queſtion, he ſaid as far as what concerned what he ſwore here, was true, and he is bound at this time to anſwer no more.

sp.speaker: Langhorne,
sp.p: Then as to Sir John Warner, I deſire my Witneſſes may be examined.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe they may be here, and ſay the ſame they did yeſterday; that he did not ſtir from his houſe at Watton all April and May.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yea, my Lord, he lived there all that while.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Year?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs.
sp.p: In year 1678.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is the time that Oates ſays he came over with him. You ſaw him all moſt every day, did not you?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs.
sp.p:
Yes, I did, only four days that I was abſent, being ſent by him to St ••
Omers at a great Feaſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And when you came back you found him there?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, I lid ••

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are his Gardner, are you not?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſtay all thoſe four days at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 4th. Watneſs.
sp.p: I was ſent to the high Kirk, and carried ſome Inſtruments for the muſick. and there I ſtayed four days, and the laſt day of April, and the firſt, and ſecond, and third of May. And I ſaw mr. Oates there in the houſe, and I ſaw him going into 〈…〉

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays that Sir. John Warner was at home all April. and May, that he himſelf was abſent but four days, that he left him there, and when he came back, found him there, and that in the four days he was at St. Omers, he ſaw Mr. Oates, which was the laſt of April, the firſt, ſecond and third of May. You don't know when mr. Oate; went away?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: No, my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was Sir John Warner there all June?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't tell that, I only ſpeak to April and May.

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: Thoſe are the two Months that fit him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton,
sp.p: Why how came you not to remember that, as well as the other two, for that is ſince?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Becauſe I took not ſo much notice of him in thoſe Times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to take more ſpecial notice of them two Months, than of the other?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: Becauſe our Rector did then come into England, and he took the charge of the Houſe upon him in the Rectors abſence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he come?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: He came the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben,
sp.p: Pray who is your Rector? What is his Name?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: Sir Francis Williams.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was Sir John Warner in June and July?

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs,
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: And where was he in Auguſt and September?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: He went out of Town, but where, I am not certain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You were Gardener there then.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why can't you as well tell me then where he was in June and July, as in April and May? Anſwer me plainly.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: I think he was there all that time, but I can't be certain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why not ſo certain for thoſe two months, as you are for the other?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs,
sp.p: Becauſe I did not take ſo much notice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How come you to take more notice of the one, than the other? That he was • ere in April and May, rather than that he was there in July.

sp.speaker: 4th. Witneſs,
sp.p: Becauſe the Queſtion, my Lord, that I came for, did not fall upon that me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now he hath anſwered plainly; when I asked the Queſtion, Why he did •• t take ſo much notice of thoſe Months, as he did of April and May? He anſwered me, 〈◊〉 cauſe the Queſtion did not fall upon thoſe months; and that, without all Queſtion, 〈◊〉 a plain and an honeſt Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt, Dolben.
sp.p: Indeed he hath forgot his Leſſon, you ſhould have given him •• ter Inſtructious.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you Mr. Langhorn, If he be to be believed, and that he doth not ſpeak •• ſly, or more than he knows, it is impoſſible that Oates Teſtimony and his can ſtand •• gether; for he directly • ffirms he ſaw Mr. Oates the laſt of April, the firſt ſecond, and •• rd of May. Now Mr. Oates ſays he was here then, ſo that theſe two cannot ſtand to
• her. The Queſtion then is, Whether he be to be believed? And whether he does 〈◊〉 come wilfully, or prepared? the Jury have heard what a kind of teſtimony he gives •• en the Queſtion was asked him, How he came to take notice of the Months of April
〈◊〉
May, more than of June and July? And why he was more ſure Sir John Warner
was there at the one time, than at the other? Why, ſaid he, Becauſe the Queſtion falls upon thoſe former months, and not upon thoſe of June or July. Now that does ſhake all that was ſaid before, and looks as if he came on purpoſe, & prepared for thoſe months, and now this, I am afraid, will go through all your St Omers men.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, Indeed I doubt it will go a great way, to ſhake all their Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: You Gardener, what do you ſay was your Rector's name?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Sir Francis Walliams.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: And he came over in April or May, Did he?

sp.speaker: 4th VVitneſs,
sp.p: He came over the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: VVhy that is the time that mr. Oates came over, and he was one of the perſons that he ſaid came over with him.

sp.speaker: 4th VVitneſs.
sp.p: No, he came alone only with a certain Officer of the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Pray let Gifford be asked the ſame Queſtion about Sir John Warner; for if he did come, as he ſaith, from Waiton to St Omers, at that time he muſt ſee him at St. Omers, for he was at St. Omers then. The queſtion is. about Sir John Warner, if he were at Watton, or St Omers, then he could not come over with Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhen did you ſee Sir John Warner?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I ſaw him about June or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhere did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I ſaw him there in St. Omers Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhen?

sp.speaker: Gifford
sp.p: In June or July, when he invited me over to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This man does not ſerve the turn, he does not know the Month upon which the Queſtion runs.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: The firſt day of May there was a great Feaſt, St. Fortunatus and Gordianus, and then I ſaw Mr. Oates four dayes, and he was there all the month of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhere was Sir John Warner then?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: I cannot tell but at St Omers I ſaw Mr. Poole, and Sir Ro. Brett at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did mr. Poole come over with you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yet, my Lord, he did,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Witneſs, when did Mr. Poole come from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: He came firſt to St. Omers with mr. Whitebread, he was my maſter of Moſick, and he taught me, and it was impoſſible he ſhould be miſſing without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he was gone to England long before that; and he could not be at England and St Omers, at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: 5th VVitneſs,
sp.p: You ſay right, he could not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVen came he from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 5th VVitneſs,
sp.p: In the month of June or May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Or April.

sp.speaker: 5th VVitneſs.
sp.p: No, it was the month of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Theſe are but Collateral matters, mr. Langhorn, for you to ſtand upon this it ſpends time to no purpoſe; but the great Queſtion is, Friend, whether you don't miſtake the month?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, yes, (at which the people laughed) no, no, I don't miſtake the month I only ſpeak the truth according to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you ſo preciſely remember the month of May he was there; for when I asked you when he went away, you could hardly tell the month.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, Mr. Oates ſays, in the month of May he was in England but I ſay I ſaw Mr. Poole then at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But the great Queſtion is, Whether you are to be believed? We know you anſwer the Queſtion poſitively, but my reaſon why I fear you are not to be believed, is, becauſe you are ſo preciſe, that Mr. Poole taught you all May, but I ask you once more, was it in June, or was it in May?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: It was about June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: May is about June. Why then you cannot tell. Was it in June?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, may Lord, it was; it was about June. And this is nothng but • hat I know, for I actually ſaw Mr. Oates there at that time.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: I'll tell you what Mr. Langhorn, uſe your diſcretion, call whom you will, and we will hear them as long as you will; but we had ſixteen of them yeſterday, that did all ſpeak to the ſame purpoſe, but in anſwer to theſe ſixteen Witneſſes, Mr. Oates did produce, and he will produce again ſix or ſeven Witneſſes, and one of them a Papiſt, if not a Prieſt, who do ſwear that Mr. Oates was here in April and May; I'll tell you beforehand, do you as you will.

div.p: Then one Baille ſtood up, and being a Foreigner, an Interpreter was called.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where did you ſee Sir John Warner in April and May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw him actually at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What all the month of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: Yes, he ſays he converſed with him all the month of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And was he there all April, and converſed with him then?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: Yes, he ſays every day of both months. He ſays he ſaw him from the firſt Sunday in April, to the 14th of May, and converſed with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did Sir John Warner go the 14th of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays he went for one day only to St. Omers, and came back again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him, How he knows this?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he was employed about a Building by Sir John Warner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oats, and where?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: I ſpeak as to Sir Thomas Preſton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you as to Sir Thomas Preſton?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: I ſaw him at Liege.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: All the months of March, April, May, and June, he was ſtill there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When went he away?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: In the time of the Vacancies.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When is that?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: That is from the beginning of Auguſt, till the end of September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came he again?

sp.speaker: Carſent.
sp.p: When they came to School again, and that was in the 2d. or 3d. of October.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben,
sp.p: Were you with hm all that time?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: Yes, I was. He hath not been in England theſe three years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you been there?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: I have been there four years, and I never knew that he was abſent, but • n the time of nhe Vacancies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

div.p: Then ſtood up another Witneſs, who being a Dutch man, and not ſpeaking Engliſh, an Interpreter was called for him alſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what comes he for?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he comes to teſtifie. That Sir John Warner was at Watton in April; and he ſays he ſaw him there, from the 14th of April, to the 25th of April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And then to what time?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he was there till the 16th of May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Ask him where he was the beginning of April?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he was Superior there in the Houſe, and did govern.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him where he was in the latter end of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays he was likewiſe in the Houſe, ſave only one day, when he went to St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then he might have ſaid, in ſhort, he was there all April and May.

sp.speaker:
M •
Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Call John Joſeph. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: What do you ask him, Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: That which I ſay is this, That Sir, Thomas Preſton was at Liege in March, April, May, and June, in the year 1678

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every day in thoſe months?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: That I cannot well tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every other day?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I believe I did once in two or three days.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where was he in July?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: He was at Liege too. He was obliged to be ſo; but in the time of the Vacancies in Auguſt, he was abſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you ſay he was all thoſe months, March, April, May, June & July there.

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, thoſe four months I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What became of him in Auguſt, when he went, during the Vacancies, abroad? Do you know whither he went?

sp.speaker: Sir Creſw. Levins.
sp.p: Do you know whether he went into England?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: I never heard that he was in England.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When did he return again?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: When they began School, and that is in the beginning of October.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt,
sp.p: Well, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs,
sp.p: I can ſay that Mr. Oats never ſtirred out of the Colledge at that time when he ſays he came to England, that is, he ſays he came upon monday the 25th of April, but he did not, for that day he went into the Infirmary, and he ſtayed at Saint Omers all April and May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And how much longer?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs,
sp.p: A great of Junes

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there the 20th of June?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs,
sp.p: I am ſure he was, but how much longer I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he in February and March?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs,
sp.p: He was there too; in January he lay our one night, and that was at Wotton, but I am ſure he did not come over the 24th of April, N. S. as he ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: Now he ſays, it is New Stile, not Old Stile, as he ſaid yeſterday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what do you ſay?

sp.speaker: 11th Witneſs,
sp.p:
Mr. Poole was ſick, and I can remember when his Nephew went to
him into the Infirmary before he went away from the Colledge, and he gave him good Counſel, as he ſaid, and I remember that Mr. Brett was ſick at Watton, and did come home again on Horſeback, and I believe he did not ſtir out; and Mr. Poole was at St. Omers, I am ſure I ſaw him once in two or three days all April and May. He went by the name Kilingbeck.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he does not poſitively ſay he ſay Sir Robert Brett every day there, he ſays he believes he did.

sp.speaker: 11th Witneſs,
sp.p: He came into the School and gave the • oys Queſtions to diſpute of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: Call the reſt of your Witneſſes.

p.hi: Then another witneſs was called and ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 12th Wit.
sp.p: I ſaw him almoſt every other day from the time he came till he went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was the firſt time you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: The beginning of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in April there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him in April there at an Action.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did you ſee him in May there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, I can teſtifie I ſaw him the firſt day of May in the Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long ſtaid he there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: Till June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch preciſe notice?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: By his very place I could not but take notice if he were miſſing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you ſay you ſaw him in the Garden the firſt of May?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: I'll tell your Lordſhip, why, becauſe there was a great Feaſt, and he played at Nine-pins in the Garden, and I can tell what they played for.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you as to Mr. Nevil, and Sir Robert Brett's being at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs,
sp.p: I did not take ſo much notice of Sir Robert Brett, as for Nevil, I think • ſaw him once in three days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: And there is nothing ſaid of him here.

sp.speaker: Lood Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates firſt at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs,
sp.p: I firſt ſaw him in the month of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in April and May?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there all thoſe months?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: Was he there all the month of June?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs,
sp.p: He went away towards the latter end of June?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.North,
sp.p: Yeſterday you ſaid the latter end of July. Call another witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North.
sp.p: Come, you hear the Queſtion, Did you ſee Mr. Oats at St Omers, in the month of April?

sp.speaker: 14th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was there all the month of April?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there all the month of May?

sp.speaker: 14th Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: And a good part of June?

sp.speaker: 14th Witn.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: What do you ſay as to mr. Poole?

sp.speaker: 14 Witn.
sp.p: I ſaw mr Poole in the infirmary the third day of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: How came you to take notice of it ſo well, as to remember it that was the third of May?

sp.speaker: 14th Witneſs.
sp.p: It was a Feſtival day. And the Feaſt we kept was the Invention of the Holy Croſs. We had the Action the day before, and ſome that were in the Infirmary would have it Acted over again to them, and we did ſo. My Lord, within one or two days after, Mr. Hilſley went away, I diſcourſed with Mr. Oates about half an hour, he came out within a day or two after out of the Infirmary, and I ſaw him walking in the Gallery. And again, the 2d of May I ſaw him walking with one Mr. Burnaby, who arrived the day before, the firſt of May, and then I ſaw him the 3d, 4th, and fifth; in this Burnabys company; I ſaw him again the 26th of May, with a Band about his head in order to confirmation, for they alwayes have a Linnen Cloth bound about their head at ſuch a time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: Call another. (Who ſtood up,)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat can you ſay?

sp.speaker: 14 Wit.
sp.p: All that I can ſay is this, that between the ſaid month of December, 1677, and June 1678. which is the time in Queſtion, mr. Oates was never out ofthe Colledge, above one night. when he went to VVatton in January, and this is certain, that from the time that I ſaw him firſt, till the time he went away for altogether, there were not 2 days that paſſed away wherein I did not ſee him, except in the month of March, and when he was n the Infirmary the 24th of April, but then I heard that he was there—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVho did tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: 14 Wit.
sp.p: The man that keeps that part of the Houſe; and coming into my Office after my Revovery out of a fit of ſickneſs a week before Chriſtmas or thereabouts, I ſaw Mr. Oates by this Circumſtance, The Servitors of the Houſe ſaid they were glad to ſee me, and Mr. Oates being in that Place at the Refectory that was aſſigned to him I asked who he was, and they told me ſuch an one, but I had heard of his admiſſion a few dayes before. Likewiſe Mr. Oates was there when mr. Hilſley came for England, which was about the 24th of April, by his circumſtance, that he was preſent in the Refectory with ſome of the Scholars. mr. Richard Burnaby came to the Colledge about a week after mr. Hilſley went away. & mr. Oates was actually there then, & we did very much wonder that he became acquainted with him ſo quickly after his arrival. I ſay Mr. Oates was actually there when mr. Killingbeck and mr. Conqueſt came for England about the 3d. of May, by this circumſtance, that I had ſome diſcourſe with mr. Oats, & ſome others of the Scholars, that Mr. Conqueſt would by no means get out of his Bed betimes that day he was to go away, being unwilling to leave the Colledge. He wa there the 26th of May by this circumſtance, that the Biſhop dined there that day, & Mr. Oats was there confirmed that day. Mr. Oates was there alſo in June my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes he was there in June, he does not deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J Pemberton.
sp.p: And was he there all May?

sp.speaker: 14th VVitneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was, and all April, except the time he was in the Infirmary, which was 3. or 4 days.

sp.speaker: Lanmghorn,
sp.p: What do you ſay as to Pool and Nevil?

sp.speaker: 14th Witneſs,
sp.p: They were there all the whole time in Queſtion, and they were never abſent any competent time co come to England as he ſays.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: We muſt not allow that, you muſt tell us what time they were there, that we may know it.

sp.speaker: 14th Witneſs,
sp.p: They were there in March, April, May, June and July.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: But did you ſee him every day from the beginning of Chriſtmas to the time he went away in June?

sp.speaker: 14th. VVit.
sp.p: Yes except the time be was at Watton, and when he was in the Infirmary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: But was not Mr. Oates twice in the infirmary?

sp.speaker: 14th VVitneſs.
sp.p: He was I Remember there on St. Thomas of Canterbury's Day, and I remember he was there in April.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins
sp.p: I did hear you ſay ſomething of ſome body that was abſent five or ſix days, was it you?

sp.speaker: 14th Wit.
sp.p: I was ſick in the month of March, and I was in the Infirmary till about the twelve or fourteen day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins
sp.p: And did you ſee him there all that time?

sp.speaker: 14th. VVitneſs,
sp.p: I excepted that time, but I heard his voice once in that time in the next Room to the Infirmary, where I was by this Circumſtance; He uſed to come to a Table by himſelf, and it was neer the Door, and Nevil and Poole were there, as I ſaid before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: He ſpeaks much more to the purpoſe to day Mr. Langhorn than he did Yeſterday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: And much louder.

sp.speaker: Langhorne,
sp.p: I hope your Lordſhip will take notice that he ſpeaks likewiſe of the Reſidence of Mr. Poole, Sir Robert Brett, and Mr. Nevil

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes I do, Call another Witneſs.

p.hi: (VVho ſtood up, and being a Foreigner, his Evieence was likewiſe Interpreted.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw Mr. Oates, he was there, and he remebers it, till about the 25th of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did he ſee him?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays it was either in the Houſe, or in the Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: When was that, that he wa in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Interpreter,
sp.p: He ſays, he was in the Infirmary towards the latter end of December or beginning of January.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him what he ſays about Nevil and Poole.

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays they were there all June, and that Mr. Pool went away in the months of July; and he further ſays, that he being a Waterman; he carried this ſame VVilliams and March in his Boat the laſt Sunday in April.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Who is your next, Mr. Lanhorn? let him ſtand up: (which he did) when did you ſee mr. Oate at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 16 Wit.
sp.p: In the month of April, 1678.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And in May too was he?

sp.speaker: 16 Witneſs
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was mr. Poole there all that time?

sp.speaker: 16 Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, he was and ſo was mr. Nevil and mr. Breet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is Nevil now?

sp.speaker: 16 Wtineſs,
sp.p: I believe I left him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What are theſe perſons?

sp.speaker: 16 itneſs,
sp.p: The one is a Prefect, and I believe he is there ſtill. In the month of May I made mr. Killingbeck a ſute of clothes, and mr. Oates came into the ſhop, and asked me whoſe clothes they were? I ſaid mr. Killingbecks: ſaid he, how can that be? they are black: ſaid I they muſt be black, for he is in mourning.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Here is mr. Grove's wife and his maid. Then Mis. Grove ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What queſtion would you ask of her?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Mr, Oates hath ſworn, and given us ſeveral circumſtances of his coming over, and being here at that which he calls the Conſult, and that he lay at mr. Groves three or four nights; I deſire ſhe may be asked that queſtion, whether he did ſo or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know mr. Oates, Mrs. Grove?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: No I never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were there any lodgers lay at your houſe in April was Twelve month.

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord there were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you uſe to have lodgers that you do not know?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: My houſe was full of lodgers at that time: I did not know them till they lay there

sp.speaker: Sir Cre Levins;
sp.p: Why then, mr. Oate. might be there, and you not know him?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: If he lay there, I muſt needs know him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why might not a man lye with any of your lodgers three or four Nights & you not know him?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Who ſhould he lye withall my Lord?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I had a bed to my ſelf when I lay there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Oates deſcribe the chamber as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oar
sp.p: It was a place taken out of another Room, where two men were taken out, that were committed to priſon?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were there any perſons taken out of your houſe, and ſent to priſon?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In that very room he lay out of which thoſe perſons were taken.

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.p: He did not

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Upon my Oath I did lye there three or four nights more or leſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins
sp.p: You were in a diſguiſe Sir at that time, were you not, and went by another name, and ſo the woman might not know you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo:

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You cannot make any great matter of this, ſhe had ſome lodgers and ſhe knew them, but he went by a wrong name, and was in a diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Mrs. Grove ſays, ſhe knew all the lodgers that then lay there, pray ask her if ſhe did not?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember who lodged in your houſe in April was a twelve month?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Name them.

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Why, there was one pair of ſtairs', one mr. Strange by Name, and one mrs. Firz-Herbert, and above there lay my Siſter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What all the month of May and April?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And not in June?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: I am not demanded of June:

sp.speaker: Lord C. J:
sp.p: She anſwers exactly to them two months, what ſay you to March?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: They were there in March.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who lay in the Room from whence the men were taken that were carried to priſon?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: There was one mſter Crupper, and another young man that lay with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why might not hat be mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: He was one that was a Priſoner by mr. Oates Orde. And mrs Fitzherbert lay there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What, in tha Room whence the young men were taken out in April or May.

sp.speaker: Grove,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to the other months, Marth, and June, and July?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: I was not to be Examined further than the two Months I ſpoke of before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, ſhe ſays; that for April and May two Gentlemen had the Lodging that Mr. Oates ſays he lay in; but for any other time ſhe was not to be examined. Well, have you any more witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Here in Mrs. Grove's Maid: [Who ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Maid, Can you tell who lay in Groves houſe in April and May was twelve-month?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I can.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were they?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: There was my Miſtreſſes Brother and Siſter lay there.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Do you know them all? what men lay there?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: None but Maſter Strange, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Miſtris Groves ſaid, that her houſe was full.

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: Ineed my Lord, there was her Brother, Mr. York and his Wife.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But who is that Fitzherbert?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: ſhe is a Gentle woman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who lay there in march? And who lay there in July?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: maſter Strange and Miſtreſs Fizherbert.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did they lye there?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: In April, May, June, July and Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: She ſayes, they lay there in March, April, May, June, July and Auguſt, and her miſtreſs ſaid, they were there but a quarter of a year, only ſhe ſaid ſhe was to be examined no further.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to prove a Copy of the Record in the Lords houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is not to be given in Evidence here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You know how far ſuch a thing will be Evidence, manage your own evidence-well.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: It is an Extract out of the journal of the Houſe of Lords.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat particular do you pitch upon?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: About thoſe perſons who, he ſays, came over with him from St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North. Do you think it Reaſonable, that any man ſhould come to anſwer now all that ever he hath ſworn in his life? If you can ſhew any Record to contradict what he hath ſworn here, ſhew it. Do you think he can come prepared to juſtifie all he haht ſworn in any other place?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: He referred to that himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he does not.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: But he hath ſaid over and over, that Sir John Warner came over with him, Sir Thomas Preſton, and Poole.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſhould you urge that Book for? Can you make any other proof?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I would have the perſons called that took the Narrative of Irelands Trya.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you have any more Witneſſes, call them.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Won't your Lordſhip allow me to prove by Witneſſes what he affirmed • n relation to me at another Tryal?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By no means, you muſt not meddle with that:

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, why not? I will prove the words ſpoken by a VVitneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: You muſt not, that is no Evidence againſt you, nor can it be an Evilence for you:

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Then you take off the Defence that I have, & make it as if I had never any:

sp.speaker: Mr. J: Atkins,
sp.p:
That is not evidence in a Civil Cauſe, and therefore muſt not be •
dence here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you come for, Sir? what is your Name.

sp.speaker: E. Caſtlemain,
sp.p: My Name is Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Are you my Lord of Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: E of Caſtlemain,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does your Lordſhip come as a witneſs for Mr. Langhorn? Mr. Langhorn, do you call my Lord of Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I do not know what he comes for, whether he comes as a witneſs for me or not, perhaps he may.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain,
sp.p: My Lord, I come to wait upon your Lordſhip and the Court to give you an account, that ſome of the witneſſes that were ſummoned here for the Priſoners are ſo beaten and abuſed without, that they dare not come to give their Evidence, for fear of being killed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is a thing that is not to be ſuffered, let us but ſee my perſon that dares but offer to meddle with them, and I'le aſſure you we will take care to ſee them puniſhed according as they do deſerve.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: 'Tis a very unjuſtifiable thing, a thing that we will very ſeverely puniſh, if they be hindred of free ingreſs and regreſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins,
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a very horrid thing that they ſhould be ſo abuſed, they ought to have their liberty of coming and giving their Evidence here without any moleſtation.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain,
sp.p: I can aſſure your Lordſhip, that one of them was ſo beaten and bruiſed, that we cannot tell but it may coſt him his life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, we muſt look to ſuch a thing as that; for it is by no means to be allowed of. If your Lordſhip will but tell us who they are, let us but know them, and we will take care for the puniſhment of them; for we will ſhew our ſelves juſt and fair, and give them all the fair play that can be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton, Mr. Langhorn,
sp.p: have you any more Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Call the woman that kept the white-horſe-Tavern. [who ſtood up

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: To what purpoſe do you call this woman?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I deſire, my Lord, to ask one Queſtion of Mr. Oates, touching the Conſult at the white-horſe Tavern in the Strand: How many perſons met there?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Before that Queſtion be asked, I pray your Lordſhip would ask her when ſhe came to the white-horſe-Tavern to keep it?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: I don't keep it now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you keep it?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: I kept it in June, and I left it the beginning of July.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: She does not come to the time.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you keep it all the year before that?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: I kept it ſeven years before, till July laſt.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I would know of him, How many might be there at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What number of perſons do you ſay met at that Conſult?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: That Queſtion, if it pleaſe your Lordſhip, hath no reference to this Trial, neither is it at all material, but becauſe I have given the Priſoners ſo much freedom, they impoſe upon me with queſtions.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis a Queſtion they cannot expect a preciſe Anſwer to from you But yet I would have you give them as ſatisfactory an Anſwer as you can, what number there might be there at a time.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord I think there might be at the white-horſe-Tavern at a time about eighteen or twenty.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Were they in one Room, or in ſeveral Room,?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: They were in two or three Rooms.

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: Is this Mr. Oates, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, that he is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there no body never in your Tavern but who you knew? what can you tell all the people that were ever in your Tavern?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: The moſt of my Company were people that I knew.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is your Company?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: Thoſe that frequented my houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you ſay who was in your houſe April 24, 1678?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I will not undertake that, but I will give you as true an account as I can.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I'll tell you why I ask this Queſtion, Mr. Oates, did ſay in his Depoſitions before the Lords, there met fifty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At ſeveral times in the day.

sp.speaker: Langh.
sp.p: But this muſt all be in the morning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſo? ſuppoſe there met of that Company twenty in the morning, and then ſome went away, and others came in their Room, and ſo they did for divers times in the day, is not this properly ſaid of me, that there might be about fifty at that Conſult.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: He ſaith in Colemans Trial there met fifty upon the 24th of April, and afterwards they adjourned into leſſer Colloquies.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I ſay they met there the 24th day, but the Conſult was not diſſolved till the 26th day at night.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt, North,
sp.p: You muſt go only upon what is ſworn now. And we ask the Queſtion upon your Propoſal, How many were there at a time? and he ſays about eighteen or twenty at a time. Now if he proves there were eighteen at one time, twenty at another time, and ten at another, that makes about fifty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Good woman, is your houſe a little houſe?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: 'Tis a ſmall inconſiderable houſe, there is not a Room in it that will hold above a dozen, I never remembred ſo great a Company was in my houſe at one time but once in all my ſeven years, and that was a Jury of the Pariſh, and they could not be together, but were divided into three Rooms.

p.hi: Then there ſtood up a Stranger who was ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, Sir, do you know the White Horſe Tavern in the Strand?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know the biggeſt Room in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, I do, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How many my dine there?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs,
sp.p: It may be twenty people, I have ſeen a dozen or ſixteen there often.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you know the Tavern a year ago?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, this was a year ago.

p.hi: Then a ſecond witneſs ſtood up in the Court, and ſaid, that twenty five or thirty might dine in one Room that was backward, and another that was forward And a third atteſted, that he was at a wedding and there did dine above twenty in one Room next the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mr Recorder,
sp.p: If ſhe make a Jury to be in three Rooms, that i but four in a Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Thoſe Juries are ſixteen generally or more.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I don't know this Tavern my ſelf; but I thought it very conſiderable, if they had not a Room that would hold ſuch a number as he ſpoke of, fifty.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But you ſee how unfortunately it happens, the matter had not been much, if it had been proved; but it is very unlucky that theſe perſons ſhould be here in Court by whom the other is contradicted, it had been better it were never medled with. That ſhe ſhould be ſo peremptory in what ſtanders by know to be falſe, makes this contradiction in one thing to give a ſuſpicion, that all your witneſſes may be falſe in all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: Here is a Gentleman of good. Quality that ſaith, there have been fifty in a Room.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I hope neither the Court nor the Jury will reflect upon me for this.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: No, it can't do that, but it reflects upon your Evidence, eſpecially this woman.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I have been a Priſoner ſo long, and I know nothing but what Friend and Relations inform me.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: The thing was reaſonably offered, but it proves ſo unfortunately will not hold. Have you any more witneſſes to call?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I pray call them.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire I may examine them after the Kings Counſel have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton,
sp.p: You may ſay what you will for your deſence, but you muſt examine no new witneſſes then, Mr. Langhorn.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I muſt ask this Gentleman a Queſtion or two, if the Court think ſit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Propoſe them to the Court, what is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, it is in relation to a matter that happened at Irelands Tryal I know not whether it be proper, but the Queſtion I would ask is, whether Ireland were here in Auguſt or no?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: He hath given you no occaſion to ask this Queſtion at this Tryal • And is there any reaſon that we ſhould examine him to ſuch a thing? Do you thin • it reaſonable, or according to Law, that Mr. Oates ſhould be examined in your T •• a concerning what he then ſaid of Irelands being here in Auguſt, or not being here when 'tis no part of his accuſation that he brings againſt you? Can he be imagines to be prepared for ſuch a Juſtification, ſince he does not at all give any Evidence of is here?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. N rib,
sp.p: Since he gave not any occaſion or uſe for ſuch a proof now at this time, 'tis not ſit he ſhould be examined about it: Indeed yeſterday he gave it in Evidence, becauſe it concerned a circumſtance of time that related to the Priſoners the • to be tried.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Jaſt.
sp.p: 'Tis true, as my Lord ſays. That it was yeſterday proper, becauſe he gave Evidence that Fenwick and Ireland were here in Auguſt together. Now this did ſome way concern him, but you have no concern at all in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: That brought it in at that time, but this is a foreign matter it cannot be here.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Have you any more witneſſes, maſter Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p:
My Lord, Mr. Oates hath affirmed, when I asked him touching his receiving Reward, he ſaid, he had his Reward, for he had been out of purſe ſix or ſeven hundred pound, and it is my deſire to examine a couple of witneſſes touching the probability of that; for he was ſo very poor before this happened, that it is impoſſible without •
Purſe being made for him to lay out fix or ſeven hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Look you, here is the thing, he gives you an Anſwer to which he was not in the leaſt bound, nor is it to be charged by you; he ſayes he is out 700 l. but that is not any Evidence, nor is the Jury to take notice of it, nor is it to affect him. And would you have him give us an account how he came by that money?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I'll tell you how far it concerns me, the proving of his Indigency before this thing happened, will concern me thus far, —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you ſhould prove this man in an indigent condition, what is that to the preſent purpoſe, it goes to no part of the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Langkorn,
sp.p: My Lord, I ask the Queſtion for this Reaſon, for certainly if he were ſo very indigent, it cannot be imagined in probability that any man would truſt him with ſuch a great ſum, unleſs it were to give this Evidence.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: If you have any more witneſſes call them, and make an end of them; if not, then you may obſerve what you will to the Court and Jury after the Kings Council have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: But all your witneſſes you muſt call now.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Doth your Lordſhip debar me from uſing this Copy of the Record of the Houſe of Lords?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To what purpoſe would you have it read?

sp.speaker: Linghorn,
sp.p: Becauſe Bedloe therein ſays, that he had no perſon more to charge either in the houſe or out of the houſe, than what he then charged.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I was not one of thoſe perſons, then he knew nothing againſt me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis but a memorial taken by a Clerk, and do you think that his Omiſſion ſhall be concluſive to us?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: 'Tis the journal of the Lords Houſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: But can you think that can be uſed as Evidence here? If you had an Affidavit ſigned by the party, and had witneſſes to prove that he did make ſuch an Oath, you ſay ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: You cannot read that againſt his Teſtimony, you underſtand that being a Lawyer. If you have any witneſſes call them, but you pick out collataral matters, and ſpend our time to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Really if it were a thing conducing to the point, I would very much ſtretch; but it being ſuch a kind of thing as this is, he ſays he had nothing to ſay againſt any bedy elſe, and I was not named then: what is this to the Fact you are charged with?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pembert.
sp.p: Why, it may be he did not remember it then, will you conclude him that he ſhould never remember it, or ſpeak of it?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſee that now at theſe Trials, he ſays ſometimes, this is all I can remember at preſent, but by and by he recollects himſelf; would you hinder him from ſaying then what he remembers?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: Beſides, upon an Affidavit or an Anſwer in Cliancery we never allow it, unleſs we have the party to prove that he took the Oath.

sp.speaker: Langh,
sp.p: I deſire to know of Mr. Oates, whether he did diſtribute any of theſe Commiſſions, and to whom? for he hath ſaid I did.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
That which I ſay is this, thoſe Commiſſions that I named they were diſtributed, but the perſons I do not know; I know the Commiſſions were for thoſe
five perſons, and in July or Auguſt he did ſay he had diſtributed them, but he ſaid not to whom, only one indeed the ſent by his Son to the eldeſt Son of the Lord Arundel of Warder to be Commiſſary General, and he came back, and ſaid, it was delivered.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: You do not ſpeak of any other?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: I do not recollect that I know of any other.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I ask for this reaſon, becauſe, in the Lords houſe he hath charged me, that I ſent my Lord Arundels Commiſſion, and that I ſent it by my ſon, and that he ſaw a letter in my Chamber of the receipt of it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, there is ſome part of the Evidence that does reflect upon the Lords, which I charge not upon Mr Langhorn, becauſe I would not diſcover my Evidence againſt the Lords, He goes now to expatiate upon the Informations, but I hope the Court will excuſe me becauſe I reſerve it for another Trial.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I deſire Mr. Lydcot may be asked whether he did not hear Maſter Oates at a former Trial, ſay, (for ſo I find it in the Narrative,) (it was at Colemans Trials) that he came to me the next day after the Conſult, and communicated it to me, and that he never ſaw me afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know any Teſtimony Mr. Oats gave concerning Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: You are not the perſon that took the Trial, are you?

sp.speaker: Lydcot,
sp.p: I know nothing of the buſineſs at all, I was at the Trial, but I cannot particularly ſpeak what was ſaid there.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: The perſons that took the Trial were ſummoned to be here. Call Mrs. Sylliard. (But ſhe appeared not) Call Mr. Blayney.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Blayney, what would you ask him?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: I would know of him what Mr. Oates hath teſtified concerning me?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know what Mr. Oates ſaid concerning Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney,
sp.p: When, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Langh.
sp.p: At Colemans Trial, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney
sp.p: My Lord, I was preſent at Colemans Trial, and I remember Mr. Oates did ſay ſon ething about Mr. Langhorn, but I have not my Book here, I cannot tell what it was.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Here is the Book, Sir, here is his Narrative.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney,
sp.p: That was not printed by my Copy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: Who were they that did take it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney,
sp.p: Of my own knowledg I don't know whoſe Copy it was, but by hear ſay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It was taken as well as it could be taken, but you muſt not urge that which is but an Hiſtorical Narrative againſt him.

sp.speaker: M. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Mr. Langhorn, do you think to convict a man by an Hiſtory? To ſay that a man is forſworn becauſe he does not ſwear as that Hiſtory ſays he did ſwear

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We will do you all the right, and give you all the fair play we can; but we are of opinion that it ſignifies nothing, that you can make no uſe of it.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: If I can have no light, how can I imagine what they will charge me with?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you in any other Caſe obſerved it? If a man be indicted of Felony or Treaſon, any Capital Crime, he is clapt up, and is not permitted to have a Copy of the Indictment nor he cannot by Law.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: They know ſomething of what they are accuſed for, they are confronted before a Juſtice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton,
sp.p: Why, I'll ſuppoſe you had been examined, do you think your Examination would have been Evidence for you here?

div.p: Then one Elizabeth Sylliard was called, but affirming, That She durſt not ſpeak, unleſs the Court would promiſe her protection againſt the Rabble, becauſe ſome of the Witneſses had been abuſed; which the Court not being able to do otherwiſe than by promiſing to puniſh thoſe that offered to meddle with her if ſhe brought them before them, She was, by Mr. Langhorns conſent, ſet aſide, and not examined.

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: She comes in relation to a point that happened at Readings Trial, where Mr. Bedloe did depoſe, That he did not ſay all he could have ſaid againſt Mr. Whitebread, and Mr. Fenwick, but he knew more againſt them than he gave in Evidence at their firſt Trials.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton,
sp.p: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: That I take to be a kind of Perjury in him; for they are ſworn, To ſpeak the Truth, the whole Truth, and nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: Is this mateiral in your Caſe what he ſaid about Whithebread and Fenwick?

sp.speaker: Langhorn,
sp.p: It makes it material to make him uncreditable.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: Mr. Whitebread made that objection, but he was anſwered; for he was told, that he could not tell all that he knew at that time, becauſe he was in treaty with Mr. Reading about the leſſening his Evidence againſt them, and the Lords in the Tower, and the Lords were to judge what meaſure they ſhould have from him by his kindneſs to Whitebread and Fenwick. If you have no more, the Kings Counſel will go on.

sp.speaker: Sir. Cr. Levins,
sp.p:
My Lord & Gentlemen of the Jury, you have heard the Evidence that Mr. Langhorn hath given for the making of his defence, which hath been principally to reflect upon Mr. Oates; and he firſt calls mr. Hilſly to prove that whereas mr. Oates did ſwear he came over with him, he affirms he did not; but it falls out, that mr, Oates hath counterproved him by ſuch a circumſtance as does contradict him in what he ſays; for ſpeaking of the loſs of his money, Hilſly ſaid, ſome body elſe had told him of it; but producing his Witneſs for that, he only offirms, that Mr. Oates in his company was told, that mr. Hilſly had loſt his money, but not how nor where; but mr. Oates gives you a particular circumſtance, that he was cheated by a perſon he lent his money to, and that left him to pay the reckoning, which m. Hilſly does confeſs was true, and which he could not hear from the others, for the others did never know it Gentlemen, they have brought you a great many other witneſſes to prove, that Mr. Oates was not in England on the 24th of April, the time he ſays he was, and they all agree to that time, • ho' as to other times they are not ſo exact; but we ſhall give you as plain and as full an Evidence that he was here at that time as that you are there now, and ſhall very fully ſatisfie you in it For that of Sir John Warner, and Sir Thomas Proſton they are matters, that were tranſacted beyond Sea, to be ſure they did not come over by thoſe Names, no more did mr. Oates himſelf; therefore it would be hard to find out theſe Perſons, or to give you ſo particular an account of them that were thus in Diſguiſes, and had changed their Names: but truly if that were a matter done in England, it were far more eaſie for us to confront their Teſtimony in that; for matters that are done here • ye more ready for our proof than thoſe that are done beyond Sea; for the laſt woman that he called which was the woman about the White Horſe Tavern, her Evidence
would have gone as punctually for truth, if it had been a matter done in Flanders as any thing could be in the world: but it happening to be near home, it hath the ill fortune to meet with a very ſudden Anſwer, which is a manifeſt proof how they ſtretch to help themſelves, and in my opinion this contradiction overthrows all their Evidence. Gentlemen, we will call our Witneſſes, and prove it as plainly as any thing can be in the world, that Mr. Oates was here at that time. Firſt ſwear VVill. VValker (which was done)

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Do you know Mr Oats

sp.speaker: Mr Walker
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have known him ſeven or eight years.

sp.speaker: Lord C. J.
sp.p: VVhen did you ſee him in England laſt year?

sp.speaker: Mr Walker.
sp.p: I ſaw him the latted end of March 1678. or towards the middle of April following, I ſaw him then in a diſguiſe, in ſo much as that I knowing what he was & what he had been I could not a great while recollect the face of the man, & it was a great trouble tom, that having known him ſo many years, I ſhould not then know him. I went home, but could not recollect my ſelf that night; but before I roſe again the next morning I did recollect my ſelf that it was Titus Oats, and I preſently turned my ſelf out of my bed and went to a Gentlewon an whoſe name I did not then well know to inquire of her about it. After the Salutation, ſaid I, How does Mr Oats ſaid ſhe, knocking her hand upon the Counter, He is an undone man: VVhy, what is the matter, ſaid I, He is turned, ſaid ſhe, to the Church of Rome: Do you know where he is, ſaid I?
